prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Each of the correlator windows are set to 1.875 GHz bandwidth to maximum the continuum sensitivity. Baseband 1 is centered on 12CO J=2-1 and is observed in FDM mode to achieve 1.3 km/s velocity resolution. The fourth baseline coveres both DCO+ and DCN J=3-2, also in FDM mode. We have centered the correlator bands on these line since they can be observed simultaneously with the continuum with no loss in continuum sensitivity, and if detected, will provide valuable information on the kinematics and chemistry in the disk; we otherwise have no requirements on the spectral line observations. The remaining two correlator windows (basebands 2 and 3) observe the continuum in TDM.

The data rate in this proposal exceeds the recommended data rate by 5%. The spectral lines observations of 12CO/DCN/DCO+, which are obtained with no loss in continuum sensitivity, may provide extremely valuable information on the kinematics and chemistry within the disk if detected, and thus enhances the archival value of these observations.

Our goal is to measure the substructure in circumstellar disks at the highest angular resolution available to ALMA in Cycle 3. This angular resolution is essential to resolve any gaps in the disks, as demonstrated by the ALMA HL Tau image (see Figure 1 in the proposal).
The maximum angular scales for the continuum emission in the disks will be approximately 2-3 arcseconds as shown in Figure 3 in the proposal. This is larger than the angular scale that can be recovered with the most extended configuration (C36-8) needed for this program. Per the rules for this proposal call (see page 24 of the ALMA Proposers Guide V1.0), the compact configurations required to observe the larger angular scales must be requested in a separate science goal, which we have done in science goals 5, 6, and 7. Note that observations in a compact configuration are not needed for AS 209, IM Lup, and MWC 480 since suitable compact data is available in the ALMA archive. The largest angular scale requested in science goals 1, 2, 3, 4, and 8 then has been set to 0.4 arcseconds to conform with the shortest baselines available in configuration C36-8. Figure 2 and 4 in the proposal show simulated images in CASA where we have combined the extended and compact configuration data based on the sensitivity requested in the proposal to demonstrate we can recover the large angular scales.

The required sensitivity is based entirely on the continuum observations. We have no requirements on the line sensitivity. The goal of our proposal is to survey the disk structure at the highest angular resolution offered in Cycle 3. Since the density perturbations at this resolution are unknown, and indeed the goal of the proposal is to measure them, we set the observing requirements based on the disk that has the lowest surface brightness in science goals 1, 2, 3, 4 and 8, and adopted the same observing parameters for all sources. This implies that the brighter disks in our survey will have higher signal to noise per resolution element, and thus more subtle structures will be detectable.
The surface brightness was estimated based on existing submillimeter observations from CARMA, SMA, and ALMA as listed in Table 1. All of the sources by design have centrally peaked surface brightness profiles. We estimated the average surface brightness within the central resolution element by taking the peak flux in Table 1 and scaling it to the resolution of our observations. Thus for DR Tau listed in science goal #2, the faintest disk in the sample and also the disk with the lowest derived surface brightness, the peak flux density is 80 mJy/beam at 0.61" resolution. At the desired angular resolution of 0.037" with ALMA, the average flux density is 80 mJy/beam * (0.037/0.61)**2 = 0.29 mJy/beam. We aim to achieve a signal to noise ratio of 15 per resolution element on average which will enable us to detect a gap that is 50% depleted at the 3 sigma level per resolution element. (The signal to noise by azimuthally averaging the gap will be significantly higher, but depends on the radius of the gap.) Thus we request a rms noise of 19 microJy/beam for DR Tau at 0.037" resolution.
A sensitivity of 19 microJy was adopted for scheduling blocks 2, 3, 4, and 8. For scheduling block 1, the sources are at a higher absolute declination than DR Tau, and the OT was estimating 15% longer time per source to reach the nominal sensitivity. In the interest of conserving time in the most extended array configuration, for science goal 1 only, we changed the required sensitivity to 20 microJy instead of 19 microJy to maintain approximately the same time per source without any impact on the science objectives.

The goal was to observe the extended continuum emission, which will be on scales of up to 2-3 arcseconds as shown in Figure 3 of the proposal. This sets the maximum angular scale.
The angular resolution was set to have sufficient overlap in uv spacings with the high angular resoluton observations in science goals 1-4 and 8. According to the technical handbook, configuration C36-8 provides baselines between 346m and 9700m. The three configurations that provide broad uv overlap with C36-8 and recover angular scales up to 3" are C36-4 and C36-5. Based on our simulations, C36-5 provided better image quality than C36-4. Therefore, from Table 7.1 in the ALMA Technical Guide on page 83, the desired resolution is 0.2 arcseconds.

The required sensitivity is based entirely on the continuum observations. There are no sensitivity requirements for the spectral line observations.
The observations in the science goals are requested to recover the extended emission that cannot be detected in the extended configuration (C36-8) observations requested in science goals 1, 2, 3, 4, and 8. Per the ALMA Proposer's Guide (page 24), observations to recover the more compact spacings for observations in configuration C36-8 must be requested in a separate science goal.
The sources are all brighter than 100 mJy in the continuum at 1.3mm (see Table 1 in the proposal). The expected surface brightness of the faintest disk in our sample is DR Tau with a mean surface brightness of 8.9 mJy/beam for the requested angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec. The requested sensitivity will achieve a signal to noise ratio of ~ 200 on the peak emission. Thus these data will have sufficient signal to noise to combined with the extended configuration observations to recover all of the flux. This was confirmed with our simulations as illustrated in Figures 2 and 4 of the proposal, which were generated in CASA using the compact and extended configurations at the proposed sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The ALMA discovery of the astonishing concentric ring morphology in the disk around the young star HL Tau strongly suggests that planet formation is in full progress by an age of 1 Myr. It motivates new observations designed to understand whether the ring morphology is unique to the HL Tau system or a central characteristic of young massive disks, and to determine what additional structural features may be pervasive in disks. We propose to exploit the new long baseline capabilities provided in Cycle 3 to image at 5 AU (35 milliarcsecond) resolution a carefully selected sample of nine disks in the nearest star forming regions. These disks were selected to have properties similar to HL Tau in that they surround young stars (age < 2 Myr), contain centrally-peaked surface brightness profiles at the resolution of current observations (150-500 mas), and are among the brightest disks accessible for long-baseline imaging with ALMA. The proposed survey will identify the predominant structural features that are present in young massive disks, and begin to explore the anticipated diversity in planetary architectures at the time of formation that is waiting to be revealed by ALMA.
